latest weather stories, photos and videos.Climate in crisisScience newsNOAA/STARU.S. NEWSCategory 4 Humberto and Tropical Storm Imelda threaten Bahamas and parts of U.S.NOAA/NESDIS/STARRHURRICANESTropical depression forms near Bahamas as Hurricane Humberto rips through the AtlanticTOP VIDEOSunday TODAYTwo Big Storms Form in the Atlantic: Where Are They Heed?Sunday TODAYSoutheast Braces for Rain, Flooding From Potential Tropical StormWeekend NightlyAt least 4 de after flash flooding in ArizonaWeekend NightlyCarolinas declare states of emergency, brace for storm threatCLIMATE IN CRISISMark Bowler / Nature Picture Library / Getty Images fileClimate in CrisisGiant trees of the Amazon get taller as forests fatten up on carbon dioxideAngela Piazza / The Corpus Christi Caller-Times via USA Today Network fileScience NewsIn South Texas, a town struggles for waterCharly Triballeau / AFP - Getty ImagesClimate in CrisisChina les nations with new climate plans, defying U.S. climate denialSee AllA tropical storm is moving toward the Southeastern coast of the United States, as Hurricane Humberto develops into a Category 4 in the Caribbean.The tropical disturbance is forecast to move north next to Florida's Atlantic coast and towards South Carolina. Tropical storm moves towards Southeastern U.S.MORE NEWS2d agoHurricanesHurricanesTwo storms are churning in the Atlantic, but only one is a threat to the U.S.Because the two storms are so close, they are subject to each other's influence and a phenomenon called the Fujiwhara effect.3d agoU.S. newsU.S. newsParents of Camp Mystic camper missing in floods say they're 'devastated' by plan to reopenThe Texas camp's owners told families it would partially reopen next year and that a memorial would be built to those killed in the flooding. 3d agoStormsStormsTropical Storm Humberto forms in the Atlantic as Hurricane Gabrielle takes aim at the AzoresA hurricane warning was in effect for the volcanic archipelago, which could experience dangerous conditions from Gabrielle.4d agoWildfiresWildfiresXcel Energy will pay $640M to settle claims from dely Denver-area wildfire Investigators found a sparking power line owned by Xcel was one of the causes of the fire that was fanned by high winds. 4d agoU.S. newsU.S. newsCamp Mystic plans to reopen in Texas next summer, a year after 27 were killed in floods The camp announced plans to build a memorial to the girls who died.6d agoHurricanesHurricanesHurricane Gabrielle swirls in the Atlantic as Tropical Storm Narda forms off MexicoGabrielle was centered som 320 miles southeast of Bermuda and moving north-northwest at 10 mph.9d agoU.S. newsU.S. news2-year-old who was swept away by California floodwaters is found de The boy was with his father when the vehicle was washed away Thursday along historic Route 66 in Barstow. The father was found alive.10d agoScience NewsScience NewsScientists predict wildfire smoke will be most costly climate-related health hazard New research provides some of the most extensive modeling of the growing health toll of wildfire smoke on public health in the U.S.13d agoStormsStormsMario restrengthens to tropical storm off Mexico's Pacific coast but not threatening landMario first gained tropical storm strength Friday before it weakened into a tropical depression just hours later.18d agoCalifornia WildfiresCalifornia WildfiresGrove of giant sequoia trees burns in California's Sierra National ForestSome of the trees, estimated to be 3,000 years old, were wrapped with fire-resistant foil blankets.21d agoHurricanesHurricanesHurricane Kiko weakening, may bring life-threatening waves to HawaiiKiko is expected to weaken to a tropical storm by late Monday as it steers north of Hawaii. Lo MoreLATEST ON NBC NEWS28m agoGiants star Malik Nabers carted off against the Chargers with an apparent leg injury2h agoGreen Bay Packers vs. Dallas Cowboys live updates: How to watch 'Sunday Night Football,' time, channel and more2h agoEric ams drops out of New York City mayoral race3h agoTrump says he'll attend gathering of generals to tell them 'how well we're doing militarily'4h agoLive Updates: Church attack leaves 2 de, 8 injured; suspect killed in shooting5h agoSen. Chuck Schumer says he has 'no faith in Trump's judicial system' after Comey indictment5h agoDemocrats need a 'serious negotiation' to avoid a shutdown, Sen. Chuck Schumer says6h agoThune digs in on funding bill, accusing Democrats of holding the government 'hostage' 8h agoTennis star apologizes after outburst about Chinese fans coughing sparks outrage8h agoRussell M. Nelson, oldest-ever president of Mormon church, dies at 1019h agoMoldovans cast ballots in a tense election plagued by Russian interference claims10h agoWho won the Cowboys' Micah Parsons tre? The NFL finds out tonight10h agoColombian president accuses U.S. of violating international law after his visa is revoked10h agoRussia launches dely aerial attack on Ukraine as Poland scrambles jets11h agoBefore Trump touted the drug leucovorin for autism, these families h alrey tried it12h agoIran weighs response after U.N. sanctions are reimposed over its nuclear program15h agoOregon outlasts Penn State 30-24 in double overtime15h ago'Highly premeditated' attack at North Carolina waterfront bar leaves 3 de and 5 wounded17h agoPopular Egyptian 'strong man' pulls 700-ton ship with his teeth19h agoSelena Gomez shares photos of her and Benny Blanco on wedding daySee AllAboutContactHelpCareers ChoicesPrivacy PolicyYour Privacy ChoicesCA NoticeTerms of Service (Updated JULY 7, 2023)NBC News SitemapClosed CaptioningvertiseNBC Select© 2025 NBCUniversal Media, LLCNBC News LogoMSNBC LogoToday Logo

Almost immediately after they disembarked, Berry said, employees started yelling at her group: \"Go back, go back, go back. Your ship is going to leave early. You're going to miss it.\"","The ship had been told to leave the port immediately and get out to sea, where it would be safe from tsunami waves, Berry said. ","They inched through traffic and pulled up to the port as the ship was closing its gates, Berry recalled. \"It was at that moment where I actually got scared,\" she said. ","After they spending spent some time reassuring their loved ones that they'd be fine, \"we felt pretty confident that we were going to be OK,\" Berry said. ","\"We knew that we would be safe. We had confidence in the Hawaiian people, Hawaiian shelters, and also [Norwegian Cruise Line] getting us to a safe place,\" Berry said. They had been stuck at a shelter for longer than expected, in less than favorable conditions, she added, but the people in Hilo \"opened their hearts to us.\" ","Berry, who goes by \"Mandy the Cruise Planner\" on social media, has been documenting her experience on TikTok, racking up hundreds of thousands of views on the series. ","She had plenty of praise for the Norwegian Cruise Line employees but expressed some frustration with the company's delayed communications and broken promises about when the ship will return to retrieve them. She's hoping for a refund on the excursion that got derailed. ","Even still, Berry has been trying to make lemonade out of lemons. ","\"I would still do this cruise again,\" she said. \"Maybe that makes me a little odd or maybe even a little bit crazy, but I'm trying to take it all in a stride and just be appreciative that, hey, if something bad is going to happen to you, at least it's happened in paradise.\"","CORRECTION (July 31, 2025, 7:45 p.m. ET): A previous version of this post misstated where Amanda Berry was when tsunami alerts went out. She was on an excursion from Hilo, not to a volcano in ","Despite the rising waters, which he said he thinks peaked while he was out, his truck was not taken by the floods. Cellphones are not allowed because participants are encouraged to detach from screens and be present, Lacour said, so counselors are taught to listen to the PA speaker systems.","“We learned pretty much to stay calm and all of the instructions will be coming from the front office,” she said.","Lacour said flooding had never been a fear of hers, because the cabins are tall and “very far away from the water.”","“It rains there plenty,” she said, “but no one could have possibly predicted the surge.”","Lacour said her job as an emergency room resident prevented her from being a counselor this summer, but she said she wished she had been there to help. ","“Mystic is my happy place. It’s my favorite place in the world. Ted Cruz, R-Texas, spoke on the Senate floor this evening, calling the devastation he saw while touring Camp Mystic “the most horrible thing I’ve ever seen in my life.”","Cruz described the Texas Hill Country and the Guadalupe River and said that yesterday when he saw it, the river was “peaceful” but that “the morning of July 4, it rose with a ferocity that the cabins at Mystic, just about every one was 8 feet deep in water. I could see the water line. Where it rose, it shattered out the windows. The force of the water pulled furniture out of the cabins.”","“I cannot imagine the terror those girls experienced,” he said.","Cruz said crosses honoring some of those who lost their lives are displayed outside the cabin where many of the youngest campers stayed.","\"I stood in front of those crosses and just wept,” Cruz said. “While I was there, there was a mom and dad who came and knelt in front of one of those crosses. They leaned over and kissed the cross, then the mom walked to the cabin and looked in the window in the cabin ... and she just stood there and wept.”","He said two of the girls whose names are on the crosses went to school with his daughter. ","Cruz also said he spoke with Trump in the immediate aftermath, saying: “I will tell you what President Trump told me. He said, ‘Ted, whatever Texas needs, the answer is yes.’”","Cruz caught some heat over the weekend for a report from The Daily Beast, which spotted him on vacation in Greece on Saturday, a day after the floods killed dozens of people in his state. ","The sighting drew criticisms from some who compared it to when he and his family took a vacation to Cancún, Mexico, during a historic winter storm in Texas in 2021. I freelanced for The New York Times and the Los Angeles Times while earning a B.A. in political science at UCLA. I was a regular at Santa Monica and Beverly Hills City Council meetings for the L.A. Times and — after an arts beat internship there — I stuck around during my senior year and successfully begged to be deployed during the Los Angeles riots. I ended up as a minor part of the team that won a Pulitzer Prize for breaking news coverage. I went to The Philadelphia Inquirer after school and soon returned to the Times as a staff writer specializing in youth culture and pop music. I worked as a staff writer at two magazines before settling in at LA Weekly as a daily news reporter for eight years. My career at NBC News started in 2018.","elementId":null,"dataAttributes":[]}],"educationAndExpertise":[],"awards":[{"type":"markup","element":"p","html":" ","elementId":null,"dataAttributes":[]},{"type":"markup","element":"p","html":"\u003cspan style=\"font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial,sans-serif; color: #000000; background-color: transparent; font-weight: 400; font-style: normal; font-variant: normal; text-decoration: none; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;\"\u003eIn 1992, I participated in the Los Angeles Times' team coverage of the L.A. riots, for which the publication won a Pulitzer Prize for breaking news. In 2006 I was recognized for investigative reporting by the nonprofit New America Media Awards for a story on Latinos vociferously opposed to those who come to the United States illegally. In the 2010s, I was a finalist multiple times for the title of online journalist of the year, bestowed by the Los Angeles Press Club. In 2016 I declined a journalism award from the group National Hispanic Media Coalition for my coverage of the effort to include more Latinos on NBC’s \"Saturday Night Live.\" I had worked with the I freelanced for The New York Times and the Los Angeles Times while earning a B.A. in political science at UCLA. I was a regular at Santa Monica and Beverly Hills City Council meetings for the L.A. Times and — after an arts beat internship there — I stuck around during my senior year and successfully begged to be deployed during the Los Angeles riots. I ended up as a minor part of the team that won a Pulitzer Prize for breaking news coverage. I went to The Philadelphia Inquirer after school and soon returned to the Times as a staff writer specializing in youth culture and pop music. I worked as a staff writer at two magazines before settling in at LA Weekly as a daily news reporter for eight years.
